I think you are wrong, I think people do care. I think they care that he 
fought so long and to give up is so tragic. I think they care that in a 
world that sometimes seems plagued with apathy, people can get lost. Life 
doesn't stop for anyone, there are still bills to pay, kids to feed and 
trash that needs to be taken out. Did I know Robin, no. Do I really care 
that he killed himself? Hell yeah I do just like I care for anyone else who 
has done it, but I will focus just on Robin for this argument. I have spent 
countless nights thinking about him seated on the floor with the belt 
around his neck. He could have just gotten up. but Robin was dedicated to 
dying. Unable to cut his wrists deep enough with a pocket knife shows A: He 
didn't have the strength or a sharp enough blade to cut through or B: it 
was too painful meaning he didn't like that kind of pain. He then looped a 
belt around his neck put it in the crack of the closet door, closed it and 
then just sat down?!!! THAT is alot of self hatred and pain to force 
yourself to do it. 

Back to the point. I care that he is dead. I care that he suffered in his 
daily life and it led him to this awful choice. Hell I am even sad because 
of your level of cynicism at such a young age. The wars somehow the wars 
feel more illusive of influence than a hollywood celebrity and when you 
grow up watching someone you do feel connected. 

The connection is real man. We can hide from it, try to discredit it, 
ignore it but like it or not we are all in this together.  We should all 
care ﻿

One does not have to place a black veil over their face and refrain from 
speaking, or remain home from work for 30 days in order to display feelings 
of real care. Most people on the planet don't receive that kind of 
attention when they die from people in their immediate circle, nor do they 
need to. There are many behaviors in ones everyday life where they can 
evoke varying degrees of care and empathy when they so choose. I get what 
you are saying and much of what you express I appreciate and even agree 
with. However death is not a big, horrible place. It is death. It has its 
own reality and experience just as life does. When one dies, it doesn't 
mean that those who remain have to stop living their lives. This all comes 
from our skewed sense of what death is and the loss that we feel when 
someone we love dies. And as for people feeing the way they do when a 
person of note dies, it is just a common sense of empathy that many humans 
experience as a species. Similar to many other emotions. Humans have the 
capacity to empathize, which may be a better word that care.﻿

Christopher, I appreciate your honesty, but I feel you are chastising 
yourself and many other people too harshly. We live in a tv culture (mind 
you I am a Polish expat living in the UK, and the same thing goes for me) 
and, as it happens, what we see is often what we believe in, even if it is 
only on a subconscious level. I was very shocked and moved by Robin's 
suicide, not because I knew the real him, but because I knew what he 
publicly showed through his passionate movie and stand up performances. 
Mind you, though, that at the end of the day it's not possible to know any 
truth about anybody at all, except for what we can see, hear, and otherwise 
experience and for how we interpret it in our own minds. Robin Williams was 
mostly consistent in his movie roles as a passionate and very humanistic 
person with a great sense of humor, so that's how many people perceived 
him. But that's the problem of the tv and the silver screen that it 
sometimes beats the real life as more impressive, more appealing. At the 
end of the day, though, is it so bad to feel compassionate, even if only 
superficially? Maybe better this, rather than frustration, anger, or just 
indifference? ﻿

Young man, I realize you're attempting here to refer to the American people 
in the general, i.e., "nobody cares" - but you're speaking in absolutes, 
erroneously - and rather arrogantly, I might add. It's what used to be 
referred to as the "glittering generalities" argumentative tactic some 
decades ago. Life, in general, has no such absolutes and it's foolish to 
attempt to clump all citizens together as you do here.
After all, you cannot possibly know the hearts and minds of over 300 
million people;
you cannot possibly know what I'M thinking or feeling, for that matter, yet 
your argument
is made in terms of clumping every single one of us together.

I assure you there are many, many good folks inhabiting this country - 
people that DO indeed care, deeply, when something like the tragic loss of 
Williams occurs. I didn't have to personally know the man to know his was a 
life of importance beyond his amazing talents, as many peoples' are - 
regardless of celebrity, there are those who matter among us and he most 
certainly was one.

I can only hope that, as you age, you gain a little more wisdom and 
humility. Attitude is no substitute for knowledge and experience; smugness 
will only serve to get the fur on your face rearranged by someone else from 
time to time, figuratively or otherwise.﻿

Of course I didn't know Robin Williams personally (and never pretended to) 
but I did know and love him through his work.I especially liked him in Dead 
Poets Society, as an amazing teacher, because I  was fortunate to have had 
a few like that. I also liked him in The Fischer King, a far-out Terry 
Gilliam film, where he plays a wounded, vulnerable person who has suffered 
a tragedy. I have had and lost more than one person close to me who was 
very talented, giving, but also very vulnerable, so Williams' death affected
me greatly, unlike the death of any other star I can think of. Because this 
kind of person is so larger-than-life and in control on the exterior that 
we can't imagine what they might be going through inside. However, unlike 
Christopher Greene, I refuse to judge Williams on his tragic death (to say 
that's who he REALLY was) but remember him the only way I really knew him, 
through all the great comedy and acting he gave us through the years which 
will live on.
            Another thing I don't like about this commentary it badmouths 
America and Americans. We Americans give more of ourselves (in both a 
percentage of our income and, more importantly, our time) than any other 
country on earth. I do and I know Williams did as well. And we also concern 
ourselves with the fate of our country in serious issues and causes, as 
Williams did, in his great comedy and charity. Surely he was, along with 
Carlin, one of the greatest satirists of his age. So Robin Williams in 
life, and America's sincere and heartfelt reaction to his passing, these 
both make me think
of the best of my country, and Mr Green's commentary seems very immature. 
Perhaps he should look in the mirror first before trashing America, and 
judging Williams by his death and not his work...﻿

O.K. You seem like a person who likes to reason things out, so I will 
address you with level reason. First... the reason Robin Williams killed 
him self is because of a *medical* condition it is Not a psychological 
condition brought on by environment, it is Chemical in nature. I know 2 
people who have this condition. It is accompanied by sever anxiety and the 
person experiencing this will do"anything" to make it stop. Sometimes 
medication to alter the chemical makeup of neurotransmitters is effective 
and some times it is not, it depends on the individual and the degree of 
the chemical disorder. Robin was at the end of his ability to cope, and in 
one of his attacks he simply Did that ANYTHING to make it stop. There is no 
Family, there is no "What will my kids think", there is no "What about my 
wife", there is no "What will they say about me in the media". There is 
only a terrifying wall of panic and fear, exhaustion from having fought it 
off for so many years and the final way out. It wasn't selfish it wasn't 
brave it wasn't cowardice and it wasn't a "Statement".   It Was... the only 
way to stop the waves of fear caused by his very sever form of chemical 
imbalance. All it took was someone to leave him alone long enough to carry 
it out.
   Now on to the second mistake you have made Christopher, Actually, second 
Major mistake and I will address it here in 3 parts (Yes it is That big of 
a mistake) and I will leave you without a reasonable doubt as to the 
reality and total truth(across the board) of my statement.
   Section b Part 1.)
What is grief. Well, apart from suicide (suicide in most cases) grief is 
the most selfish of emotions and it says NOTHING about Caring for the 
person who has died. We grieve because WE have become used to the presents 
of a person or even an object and a feeling associated with that person or 
object and now all of a sudden WE don't get to have that object or person 
around any more to GIVE US that feeling...EVER again. Now I can tell you 
that whether or not you care for someone "Give a shit" as you say is not so 
much measured by our grief, (which is real nonetheless) as *what we were 
willing to put up with and do for that person while they were Alive. 
THAT... is the measure of whether or not you "give a shit"*
   Section b Part 2.)
You say that if we are really grieving for Robin Williams that we should 
wear a black veil, not speak, not go to work, not do anything pleasurable 
and just mourn for Robin Williams for 30 days. This may well be one of the 
most misguided things I have ever listened to, but I will take into account 
that maybe your lack of experience is the father of your ideology.
   In 1997 I lost my fiance and at that point the love of my life, in a 
senseless auto accident. It was instant, it was hopeless, helpless and 
irrevocable. I did still go to work. I did still speak, I was in a kind of 
horrifying trance like a zombie but I continued with my life and I did not 
wear a black veil or pin for 30 days nor did her Mother, Father, Sister, 
Brother or our friends. As far as doing anything pleasurable I could have 
been on a 30 foot snow board with a built in waterbed and a keg of beer 
with 27 naked party girls going off of the slopes at squaw valley and there 
would have been no pleasure in it. I simply would have sat staring into 
space wondering what happened to my life and all of the things that could 
Never happen now for hers. It lasted for FAR FAR longer than a month I can 
tell you that. So...That being said, I believe you may "begin" at least to 
understand the true nature of grief being an exorcize in selfish and self 
involved feelings of deprivation  ( But then again, based on the statements 
you have made so far it is quite likely that you will just Never get it,)  
Which takes me to the next part.
   Section b Part 3.)
Many people did in fact Grieve about Robin Williams death in as much as HE 
did something for THEM. He made them forget about their troubles, put down 
their worries for the time and laugh and he did it in a way that WAS 
endearing it DID make them want to see him more because it Gave something 
to THEM, and seeking out and enjoying his work DID become a part of their 
lives. There are even people that changed the course of their lives and 
became successful standup comics because of him
and they didn't know him any better than you or I did. But I have to tell 
you, I did in fact feel a pang of loss even to the point of feeling the 
acidic chemistry brought on by emotion build up in my face. Not to the 
point of tears and only for a few minutes
but if you try to tell me that I am full of shit for feeling that way I 
will tell you that you don't understand that grief has Nothing to do with 
whether or not we truly know a person but whether there is going to be just 
enough of a missing piece to trigger the selfish feeling that WE are now 
missing something that cannot be replaced. SO... when you see some Perfect 
Stranger to Robin Williams weeping or lamenting his loss...Well, I hate to 
tell you but, they really Are  feeling that extremely selfish twinge that 
we know as grief and it IS real, just in varying degrees from the loss of 
someone more intimate. As far as a 48 hour news blip and then nothing more 
it has been *far over 30 days and it isn't over yet and isn't likely to be 
over any time soon*.
To validate you I concede to the fact that His personal life never entered 
our sphere of experience for us to feel the sting of missing a DAILY 
routine encounter with him. Nonetheless we encountered his work enough for 
him to be in the collective consciousness and conscience and now of that 
work, there will be No More. I am afraid that the feelings associated with 
that thought are valid enough however selfish and self involved those 
feelings may be, and that it has no more to do with any kind of political 
spin or statement as it corresponds to our Other daily bullshit, than His 
last act did, Which is of course ...None at all!

I DO really give a shit about Robin killing himself. I'm not wearing the 
black garb but I am searching and searching to find out why, what went on. 
I've heard of Illuminati involvement. It hurts ME to know he was hurting so 
much inside. I also fight bi-polar depression. I am also suicidal. Robin 
obviously had alot on his plate. I have depression because I haven't 
managed to be the perfect mother and basically been poor since my parents 
died when I was 21 and 30 years of age. I had to be present for my add son. 
I honestly would hope that Robin was well enough mentally to not be going 
off the deep end because he was losing his wealth. I think his family knew 
this was happening. His wife didn't check in on him the morning she left 
the house? I would have. And the woman who found him didn't sound so upset 
on the 911 call. You ask too much in the world showing so much care for 
him. You're right no one continues to care. I think he was aware of the 
pangs of life for people. I live it daily. My son has left for his own 
life...every step he takes that he doesn't make it, kills me. I have to 
live with my brother in law (my oldest sister died 3 years ago from 
hospital negligence) his new gf and their 2 year old because housing wants 
me to live in a one bedroom apt. Yeah I did this to help out this little 
new family as well as myself, but it is very trying most days. Anyway, 
whatever. I'm glad Robin"made it out" and unless you have ever been truly 
suicidal... you'd never understand that mentality. But I also think it is a 
great loss. I didn't even KNOW he had a tv program again...I haven't had 
cable for tv in YEARS. It's either cable or internet. I chose 
internet....because sometimes I get return letters! But I bet the show WAS 
good! Anyway, I DO care. Bet you don't give two shits I wrote any of this! 
That's ok, I'm used to that opinion.﻿

I agree with you on so many levels with so many topics that you bring up 
brother, I really do. But, I totally and respectfully disagree with you on 
this topic. Robin Williams was an icon to me. He was by far one of my 
favorite all time actors and his death really, truly hurt me. It always 
will. When he died, I felt like a part of me died. He was almost like 
family to me if that makes any sense at all. I related to him so well and 
no matter what it was, if his name came up in conversation, TV, Internet, 
commentary or anything at all for that matter, it had my full attention. 
From the time I got my Mork from Ork doll from Santa to the Crazy Ones, he 
was the magnet and I was the steel. I loved that guy like a brother. With 
that being said, why should I have to wear a black vale for a month to 
prove that I loved that guy and that his death really impacted my life?? My 
father who I love more than life died and I didn't do anything other than 
carry his wishes that he bestowed upon me and give him the best send off he 
could ever have hoped for.

We all mourn things in our own way brother. I can understand you directing 
your comments to Hollywood and mainstream media but to us in the trenches? 
Right next to you?﻿

Homage to Robin Williams - Written to the Tune of American Pie
A long, long time ago,
I can still remember how that Orcan used to make me smile
And I wish I had had the chance
To laugh with him, to sing and dance
And lay aside our troubles for a while

But that day in August gave me pain,
Each and every time I had to explain
Internet filled with bad news,
Talk shows giving us the blues

I’m not ashamed to say I cried
When I read about his widowed bride
A sadness grew from deep inside
The day the humor died

[Chorus]

Singin' "We have lost a hellofa guy

You played him expertly
a lost boy like you and me

You never took part in that mad game
You treated homeless people just the same
'til the day the humor died

[Chorus]

Singin' "We have lost a hellofa guy
The world has lost a hellofa guy"

[Verse 3]
Flying rubber, you called it Flubber
And Jumanji made you run for cover

You once taught an English class,
To some students who were a little crass,
About Dead Poets, as you knelt down on the grass



And as Patch Adams you were an awesome guy
Even though at first you wanted to die
You made those patients laugh
Oh, you really helped the hospital staff

And Jafar he tried to steal your lamp
But as the Genie, you're still the reigning champ
I laughed so hard that I started to cramp
That humor will never die

[Chorus]
We'll all be singin' bye-bye, Mrs. Doubtfire Guy

Singin' "We have lost a hellofa guy

But she just smiled and turned away

I then put in Jakob the Liar,
Awakenings and Mrs. Doubtfire
But God must have been joke'n'

Christopher: your commentary is wrong on so many levels I scarcely know 
where to begin.  First, I find your suggestion that Robin Williams’ death 
was politically motivated absurd and offensive.  Depression and anxiety are 
serious illnesses that have nothing to do with partisan politics.  Also, 
your repeated insistence that “nobody cares” about Robin Williams is 
monumentally arrogant.  It’s a fact that Robin Williams entertained many 
millions of people with his brilliant humor, spot-on insights, and unique 
perspective.  He connected with his audience in a very real and tangible 
way, and you’re not entitled to diminish those sentiments by projecting 
your cynical attitude onto others.  You seem to be a smart, articulate 
person, yet your remarks are extravagantly off-mark and tone-deaf.  I’m 
almost tempted to conclude that you’ve intentionally posted provocative 
remarks meant to stir up controversy and quarreling.  If that’s true, then 
you’re nothing but a common troll.﻿

rejecting,one of the tests they tried was taking her blood out and 
injecting it into a horse ! and yes the hospital transplant team have their 
own horses, after 4 weeks the blood is then taken back out of the horse and 
put back into her, apparently horse have brilliant anti rejection qualities 
in their blood, but it didn't work... she was having so much trouble 
breathing and her lung function test dropped dramatically, she was going to 
go back on the transplant list but she got a very bad kidney infection and 
also was 2.1 kg over weight, you have to be pretty fit before they will 
even consider you as a candidate, and the rules are very strict, she grew 
weaker as the time passed and then on the 23 of june 2015 the Angels came 
and  she went to be with mum and dad...my beautiful sister, i am shattered 
, but she fought so hard to stay. Till we meet again Dianne, i love you and 
miss you. xox
